If you're running GNOME, open Places -> COnnect to Server
now do I have to have openssh-server installed on the computer that is receiving the files?
No, only the client (which already comes with Ubuntu).
so I won't mess up anything if I "sudo apt-get purge openssh-server" ?
You shouldn't - but I would keep the server installed, in case you want to access your PC someday
is it safe, in the sense of hacking, to keep openssh-sever?
As long as your password isn't "foo123"

Besides... incoming connections require "port forwarding". (If you ever used BitTorrent, you'll understand.) And if you configured your router to forward port 22 to the other computer, your own isn't accessible from outside (unless you also set up another port).
my pass is 9 characters long is that good? and I never had to port forward to use bittorent
Yeah, that's good - but look up "dictionary attacks".
But like I said, your own PC probably isn't accessible yet.
You mean sshd, the server? It's automatically configured to run at startup.
